After 8 days of treatment, he developed his grade fever, diarrhea, confusion and muscle rigidity. Which of the following should be used for the treatment of this conditions?

A 46-year-old male, Prabash being treated for depression was admitted to the emergency with severe confusion and hallucinations. His mouth was dry and his face was flushed. On examination, his blood pressure was found to be 84/62 mmHg and his heart rate is 108 beats per minute. ECG of the patient reveals sinus tachycardia, prolongation of PR and QT interval and widened QRS complex. Which of the following agents would be best correct this patient’s cardiac abnormalities?
After starting your patient on imipramine, his heart rate rises to 120/min and he has blurred vision. These effects can be explained by the fact imipramine

A hypertensive patient Sattu already receiving a drug ‘X' to control his BP was prescribed a tricyclic antidepressant. This resulted in the abolition of the antihypertensive action of ‘X’. Which of the following drug can be ‘X’?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Option B (Diltiazem): Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker (CCB) that lowers BP by reducing vascular resistance and cardiac contractility. TCAs do not affect calcium channels, so diltiazem’s antihypertensive action remains unchanged.
  • • Option C (Atenolol): Atenolol is a β 1 -selective blocker that reduces BP by decreasing cardiac output. While TCAs can cause some indirect sympathetic stimulation, they do not significantly reverse the β-blocking effects of atenolol.

A 32-year-old woman with a history of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) presents to her primary care physician. She reports that her current medication, sertraline, is effective for her anxiety but has caused significant weight gain and sexual dysfunction. The physician decides to switch her to another medication. Which of the following would be the most appropriate alternative for her condition?

A 45-year-old male patient with a long history of bipolar disorder has been stabilized on lithium therapy. He presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. His serum lithium level is found to be 1.6 mEq/L. He reports feeling more lethargic than usual and has experienced some tremors. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Continue current lithium dosage and recheck in one week

options.label: D
options.text: Administer intravenous fluids and monitor renal function

questions.correct_answer: D. Administer intravenous fluids and monitor renal function

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a suspected overdose of his prescribed medication for ADHD. His girlfriend reports he was taking lisdexamfetamine as directed but recently started taking more than prescribed in an attempt to improve focus. On examination, he is agitated, has a heart rate of 120 bpm, and dilated pupils. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

A 60-year-old female with a history of depression is being treated with fluoxetine. After several months, she begins to experience increased anxiety and agitation. Upon review, her physician notes that she has recently started taking sumatriptan for migraine headaches. What is the most likely pharmacological interaction occurring in this patient?

A 50-year-old male patient with a long-standing diagnosis of schizophrenia has been stable on clozapine for several years. He presents to the clinic for a follow-up and is found to have a white blood cell count of 2,800/mm³. He denies any symptoms of infection. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Discontinue clozapine and switch to another antipsychotic

questions.correct_answer: A. Continue clozapine and monitor closely

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with a history of panic disorder presents to the emergency department with palpitations, shortness of breath, and a feeling of impending doom. questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a long history of migraines is started on topiramate as a preventive measure. After a month of treatment, she reports a significant decrease in headache frequency but also mentions new-onset tingling in her fingers and difficulty concentrating. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

options.text: Switch to a different class of antidepressants

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a long history of depression presents with complaints of severe insomnia and lack of appetite. She has been taking trazodone but states that it is not helping with her sleep. The physician considers switching her to another medication. A 28-year-old woman diagnosed with major depressive disorder has been treated with fluoxetine for several months. She now presents with persistent headache, nausea, and lethargy. The physician suspects a drug interaction with her newly prescribed medication for migraine headaches. Which of the following medications is most likely to cause this interaction?

A 45-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia is stable on risperidone. However, he has developed significant weight gain and metabolic syndrome. The psychiatrist decides to switch his medication to manage these side effects better. Which of the following medications is likely to be considered?

A 34-year-old female with bipolar disorder has been stable on lithium therapy for years. She comes to the clinic for routine monitoring and her lab results show a serum lithium level of 1.2 mEq/L. She denies any symptoms but mentions that she has recently started a low-sodium diet for weight loss. What should the physician advise her?

questions.correct_answer: C. Increase sodium intake and recheck lithium levels

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with chronic schizophrenia has been on clozapine for the past year. He presents to the clinic with worsening symptoms of paranoia and auditory hallucinations.
